Expectation1: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation1: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Story:
I stood in the workshop, the scent of sawdust thick in the air, my hands running over the handles of my tools. As a carpenter, I knew the importance of inspecting every saw, every drill, before starting the day’s structural work. Safety protocols weren’t just rules—they were lifelines, and I owed it to myself and my coworkers to make sure everything was in order. But as I reached for the oil can, Sister Maria burst in, her face pale with urgency. “The Johnsons’ house burned down last night,” she said. “They have nothing. We’re gathering food and clothes for them now. Can you help?”

My heart twisted. As a nun, compassion and service were at the core of my vows. The community expected me to be there, to offer comfort and aid in times of crisis. But the tools before me demanded my attention, too—if I neglected them, someone could get hurt. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my presence, each too important to ignore. My mind raced, caught between the call of duty and the call of compassion, unsure which path to take first.
